revised_title: Stress Softening in Locust Oviposition: The Role of Chitin in Extensible Intersegmental Membranes
tldr: The study investigates the mechanical properties of the extensible intersegmental membranes in locusts during oviposition. The main feature of biological importance is stress softening, which allows the locust to extend the membranes elastically without needing a large restoring force. The filler responsible for this phenomenon is likely the chitin fraction of the cuticle. This research contributes to understanding the toughness of biological materials and the role of chitin in stress softening.
